question: At present, ______ classification systems based on evolutionary relationships are acceptable.
Phylogenetic classification systems are based on ______ relationships between various organisms.

We now use information from many other ______ to resolve difficulties in classification.
Additional sources become important when there is no supporting ______ evidence.
Numerical Taxonomy is now easily carried out using ______.
Numerical Taxonomy is based on all ______ characteristics.
In Numerical Taxonomy, number and ______ are assigned to all the characters.
In Numerical Taxonomy, data are processed and each character is given equal ______.
Numerical Taxonomy allows hundreds of ______ to be considered at the same time.
Cytotaxonomy is based on ______ information like chromosome number and structure.
Cytotaxonomy uses chromosome number, structure, and ______.
Cytotaxonomy is based on cytological information like ______ number.
Cytotaxonomy is also used by ______ these days.
Chemotaxonomy uses the chemical ______ of the plant.
Chemotaxonomy helps resolve ______ in classification.

All observable characteristics are used in ______ Taxonomy.
Numerical Taxonomy gives equal importance to each ______.
Chemotaxonomy is based on ______ constituents of plants.
Numerical Taxonomy is carried out with the help of ______.
Fossil evidence is often not available to support ______.
Information from many other sources helps resolve ______ in classification.
Chromosome number, structure, and behaviour are part of ______ information.
Algae are ______-bearing, simple, thalloid, autotrophic and largely aquatic organisms.
Algae are chlorophyll-bearing, simple, ______, autotrophic and largely aquatic organisms.
Algae are largely ______ (both fresh water and marine) organisms.
Algae occur in a variety of other habitats such as moist stones, soils and ______.
Some algae occur in association with fungi to form ______.
Some algae occur in association with animals, e.g., on ______ ______.
The form and size of algae is highly ______.
Colonial forms of algae include ______.
Filamentous forms of algae include Ulothrix and ______.
A few marine forms of algae such as ______ form massive plant bodies.
Algae reproduce by vegetative, asexual and ______ methods.
Vegetative reproduction in algae occurs by ______.
Each fragment of an alga develops into a ______.
Asexual reproduction in algae involves production of different types of ______.
The most common type of asexual spores in algae are the ______.
Zoospores are ______ (motile) spores.
On germination, zoospores give rise to new ______.
Sexual reproduction in algae occurs through fusion of two ______.
Gametes can be flagellated and similar in size as seen in ______.
Gametes can be non-flagellated but similar in size as in ______.
Reproduction involving fusion of gametes similar in size is called ______.
Fusion of gametes dissimilar in size is termed ______.
An example of anisogamy is seen in species of ______.
Fusion between a large, non-motile female gamete and a smaller motile male gamete is called ______.
An example of oogamous reproduction is seen in ______ and Fucus.
Oogamous reproduction involves one large, ______ (static) female gamete.
In oogamy, the male gamete is smaller and ______.
Algae may be found on moist stones, soils, wood, and in association with ______.
The colonial form of algae Volvox and filamentous form Spirogyra are examples of variation in ______.
Kelps are marine algae that form massive ______ bodies.
Fragmentation is a method of ______ reproduction in algae.
Asexual reproduction in algae is most commonly through ______.
In isogamy, gametes are ______ in size.
In anisogamy, gametes are ______ in size.
In oogamy, the female gamete is non-motile and the male gamete is ______.
